questions.Q: The curvature of $$\vec r\left( t \right) = \left\langle {t,3\sin t,3\cos t} \right \rangle$$ is:
questions.E: The tangent and unit tangent vectors for this function are:  $$\\ \vec r'\left( t \right)  = \left\langle {1,3\cos t, - 3\sin t} \right\rangle \\ \vec T \left( t \right)  = \left\langle {\frac{1}{{\sqrt {10} }},\frac{3}{{\sqrt {10} }}\cos t, - \frac{3}{{\sqrt {10} }}\sin t} \right\rangle  \\$$  The derivative of the unit tangent is,$$\\ \vec T'\left( t \right) = \left\langle {0, - \frac{3}{{\sqrt {10} }}\sin t, - \frac{3}{{\sqrt {10} }}\cos t} \right\rangle \\$$ The magnitudes of the two vectors are,$$\\  \left\| {\vec r'\left( t \right)} \right\|  = \sqrt {1 + 9{{\cos }^2}t + 9{{\sin }^2}t}  = \sqrt {10} \\ \left\| {\vec T'\left( t \right)} \right\|  = \sqrt {0 + \frac{9}{{10}}{{\sin }^2}t + \frac{9}{{10}}{{\cos }^2}t}  = \sqrt {\frac{9}{{10}}}  = \frac{3}{{\sqrt {10} }}\\$$ The curvature is $$\kappa  = \frac{{\left \| {\vec T'\left( t \right)} \right \|}}{{\left \| {\vec r'\left( t \right)} \right \|}} = \frac{\frac{3}{\sqrt{10}}}{\sqrt{10}} = \frac{3}{{10}}$$

questions.Q: The length of the curve $$ \vec r\left( t \right) = \left\langle {2t,3\sin \left( {2t} \right),3\cos \left( {2t} \right)} \right\rangle$$ on the interval $$0\leqslant t \leqslant 2\pi$$ is:
questions.E: The arc length can be written as $$\\ L = \int_{{\,a}}^{{\,b}}{{\left\| {\vec r'\left( t \right)} \right\|\,dt}}\\$$ We will first need the tangent vector and its magnitude:$$\\ \vec r'\left( t \right)  = \left\langle {2,6\cos \left( {2t} \right), - 6\sin \left( {2t} \right)} \right\rangle \\ \left\| {\vec r'\left( t \right)} \right\|  = \sqrt {4 + 36{{\cos }^2}\left( {2t} \right) + 36{{\sin }^2}\left( {2t} \right)}  = \sqrt {4 + 36}  = 2\sqrt {10}\\$$ The length is then, $$\\ L  = \int_{{\,a}}^{{\,b}}{{\left\| {\vec r'\left( t \right)} \right\|\,dt}} = \int_{{\,0}}^{{\,2\pi }}{{2\sqrt {10} \,dt}} = 4\pi \sqrt {10}$$

questions.Q: The vector equation of the tangent line to the curve given by $$\vec r\left( t \right) = {t^2}\,\vec i + 2\sin t\,\vec j + 2\cos t\,\vec k $$ at $$t=\frac{\pi}{3}$$ is:
questions.E: The tangent vector is $$ \vec r'\left( t \right) = 2t\,\vec i + 2\cos t\,\vec j - 2\sin t\,\vec k \\$$ This vector at $$t=\frac{\pi}{3}$$ is $$\\ \vec r'\left( {\frac{\pi }{3}} \right) = \frac{{2\pi }}{3}\,\vec i + 2\cos \left( {\frac{\pi }{3}} \right)\,\vec j - 2\sin \left( {\frac{\pi }{3}} \right)\,\vec k = \frac{{2\pi }}{3}\,\vec i + \vec j - \sqrt 3 \,\vec k \\$$ We also need the point on the line at $$t =\pi/3$$ so, $$\\ \vec r\left( {\frac{\pi }{3}} \right) = \frac{{{\pi ^2}}}{9}\,\vec i + \sqrt 3 \,\vec j + \,\vec k \\$$ The vector equation of the line is then,$$\\ \vec r\left( t \right) = \left\langle {\frac{{{\pi ^2}}}{9},\sqrt 3 ,1} \right\rangle  + t\left\langle {\frac{{2\pi }}{3},1, - \sqrt 3 } \right\rangle$$

questions.Q: The 1st order partial derivative respect of x for the function $$f\left( {x,y,z} \right) = 4{x^3}{y^2} - {{\bf{e}}^z}{y^4} + \frac{{{z^3}}}{{{x^2}}} + 4y - {x^{16}} $$ is:
Given $$f\left( {x,y,z} \right) = {x^4}{y^3}{z^6}$$, the value of $$\frac{{{\partial ^6}f}}{{\partial y\partial {z^2}\partial y\partial {x^2}}} $$ is:
questions.E: $$\frac{{\partial f}}{{\partial x}} = 4{x^3}{y^3}{z^6}\rightarrow \frac{{{\partial ^2}f}}{{\partial {x^2}}} = 12{x^2}{y^3}{z^6} \rightarrow \frac{{{\partial ^3}f}}{{\partial y\partial {x^2}}} = 36{x^2}{y^2}{z^6} \rightarrow \frac{{{\partial ^4}f}}{{\partial z\partial y\partial {x^2}}} = 216{x^2}{y^2}{z^5} \rightarrow \frac{{{\partial ^5}f}}{{\partial {z^2}\partial y\partial {x^2}}} = 1080{x^2}{y^2}{z^4} \rightarrow {{\frac{{{\partial ^6}f}}{{\partial y\partial {z^2}\partial y\partial {x^2}}} = 2160{x^2}y{z^4}}}$$
